content.question: A scientist is studying <math alttext="P C Bs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>P</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in tertiary consumers. She wants to determine if <math alttext="P C Bs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>P</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> can be found in tertiary consumers even though these compounds were banned in the United States in the 1970s. Which of the following best identifies a testable hypothesis for the study?

choices.label: <math alttext="P C Bs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>P</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> are highly soluble in water, so it is unlikely that the compounds will be found in the liver or kidneys of tertiary consumers because the compounds have been banned.

<math alttext="P C Bs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>P</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> are persistent organic compounds that are fat-soluble, so they should be found in the fatty tissues of tertiary consumers even though the compounds have been banned for decades.

<math alttext="P C Bs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>P</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> have synergistic effects with other toxins in the environment and are broken down in water and soil, so most tertiary consumers are not directly exposed to them.

<math alttext="P C Bs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>P</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> are acutely toxic to most forms of life and quickly kill most organisms upon exposure; therefore, tertiary consumers today would be expected to have high levels of the compound in their tissues.

content.answer: <math alttext="P C Bs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>P</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> are persistent organic compounds that are fat-soluble, so they should be found in the fatty tissues of tertiary consumers even though the compounds have been banned for decades.
